documents.title: Build, debug & deploy with AI
documents.summary: This document introduces Gemini CLI, a tool that allows users to query and edit codebases, generate applications, and automate workflows using AI directly from their terminal.

documents.title: Welcome to Gemini CLI documentation
documents.summary: This documentation provides a comprehensive guide to installing, using, and developing Gemini CLI, a command-line interface for interacting with Gemini models.

documents.title: Gemini CLI release notes
documents.summary: This document provides information on the release channels for Gemini CLI, including nightly, preview, and stable versions. It also details announcements and new features for various versions, such as improved model support, new extensions, and UI enhancements.

documents.title: Gemini CLI authentication setup
documents.summary: This document explains how to authenticate with Gemini CLI, offering several methods based on user type and scenario, including Google account login, API keys, and Vertex AI authentication options.

documents.title: Gemini CLI installation, execution, and deployment
documents.summary: This document explains how to install and run the Gemini CLI, detailing different methods like standard installation, running in a sandbox via Docker/Podman, and execution from source or GitHub. It also covers the underlying deployment architecture including NPM packages, build processes, and the sandbox image.

documents.title: Gemini CLI
documents.summary: This document provides an overview and links to detailed documentation for the Gemini CLI, covering its commands, customization options, advanced features, and non-interactive usage for automation.

documents.title: Gemini CLI examples
documents.summary: This document provides examples of how to use Gemini CLI for various tasks, including renaming files based on content, explaining code repositories, combining spreadsheets, and writing unit tests.

documents.title: How to contribute
documents.summary: This document outlines the process for contributing to the Gemini CLI project, covering prerequisites, code and documentation contribution guidelines, and development setup.

documents.title: Gemini 3 Pro and Gemini 3 Flash on Gemini CLI
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable and use Gemini 3 models (Pro and Flash) within the Gemini CLI, covering setup, usage limits, model routing, and specific instructions for Gemini Code Assist.

documents.title: Custom commands
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and manage custom commands in Gemini CLI using TOML files, covering file locations, naming conventions, argument handling, and shell command execution.

documents.title: Gemini CLI configuration
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure the Gemini CLI, detailing the different configuration layers, file locations, and available settings within the `settings.json` file.

documents.title: Gemini CLI Architecture Overview
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture of the Gemini CLI, detailing its core components: the CLI package for user interaction and the Core package for backend logic and API communication, along with the system's tool extensibility.

documents.title: Get started with Gemini CLI
documents.summary: This document provides a quickstart guide to installing, authenticating, and configuring the Gemini CLI tool for command-line use. It explains how to get started with basic usage and points to further documentation for more advanced features.

documents.title: Checkpointing
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Gemini CLI's Checkpointing feature, which automatically saves your project's state before AI modifications and allows you to revert to a previous state using the `/restore` command.

documents.title: Sandboxing in the Gemini CLI
documents.summary: This document explains how to use sandboxing in the Gemini CLI to isolate AI operations from your host system, covering installation, different sandboxing methods like macOS Seatbelt and container-based solutions, and configuration options.

documents.title: CLI commands
documents.summary: This document describes the built-in commands for the Gemini CLI, categorized by their prefixes (`/`, `@`, `!`), and explains their functionalities and usage.

documents.title: Gemini CLI for the enterprise
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure Gemini CLI for enterprise environments using system-level settings, wrapper scripts, and tool restrictions to enhance security and manage user access.

documents.title: Gemini CLI model selection (`/model` command)
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the /model command in Gemini CLI to select and configure the Gemini model used for your tasks, recommending the Auto setting for most users.

documents.title: Session Management
documents.summary: This document explains how Gemini CLI automatically saves and manages conversation sessions, detailing how to resume, list, and delete sessions, as well as configure session retention policies.

documents.title: Headless mode
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Gemini CLI in headless mode, allowing programmatic execution via command line scripts and automation tools. It covers basic usage, different output formats (text, JSON, streaming JSON), file redirection, and configuration options for scripting and CI/CD pipelines.

documents.title: Gemini CLI keyboard shortcuts
documents.summary: This document lists and explains the default keyboard shortcuts available in the Gemini CLI for various actions like text editing, history navigation, and UI control.

documents.title: Agent Skills
documents.summary: This document explains Gemini CLI's Agent Skills feature, which allows extending the CLI's capabilities with specialized, on-demand expertise packaged as self-contained directories. It covers how skills are discovered, managed via interactive commands and terminal utilities, and structured with a `SKILL.md` file for metadata and instructions.

documents.title: Tutorials
documents.summary: This tutorial explains how to set up a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server, using the GitHub MCP server as an example, and configure it within your Gemini CLI project settings.

documents.title: Observability with OpenTelemetry
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable and configure OpenTelemetry for Gemini CLI to send telemetry data to Google Cloud or local files for observability, performance monitoring, and debugging.

documents.title: Gemini CLI settings (`/settings` command)
documents.summary: This document explains how to control Gemini CLI settings using the `/settings` command and details various configurable options for UI, output, IDE, model, context, tools, security, and experimental features.

documents.title: Themes
documents.summary: This document explains how to customize the appearance of the Gemini CLI by changing its color theme, either by selecting a pre-defined theme or by creating and loading custom themes from JSON files.

documents.title: Uninstalling the CLI
documents.summary: This document explains how to uninstall the Gemini CLI, providing distinct methods for users who installed it via npx versus a global npm installation.

documents.title: Token caching and cost optimization
documents.summary: This document explains how the Gemini CLI optimizes API costs by utilizing token caching for API key and Vertex AI users, and how to view usage statistics.

documents.title: System Prompt Override (GEMINI_SYSTEM_MD)
documents.summary: This document explains how to override the default system instructions for the Gemini CLI by using the GEMINI_SYSTEM_MD environment variable to point to a custom Markdown file.

documents.title: Memory Import Processor
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Memory Import Processor feature to modularize GEMINI.md files by importing content from other files using the @file.md syntax, including details on path formats, security, and debugging.

documents.title: Web fetch tool (`web_fetch`)
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the `web_fetch` tool within the Gemini CLI to process information from one or more URLs provided in a natural language prompt.

documents.title: Gemini CLI tools
documents.summary: This document explains how the Gemini CLI uses built-in tools to interact with the local environment, access information, and perform actions, detailing the process and security considerations involved.

documents.title: Trusted Folders
documents.summary: This document explains the Trusted Folders feature in the Gemini CLI, which enhances security by requiring user approval for folders before the CLI loads project-specific configurations.

documents.title: Shell tool (`run_shell_command`)
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the `run_shell_command` tool in the Gemini CLI for executing shell commands, including interactive sessions and command restrictions.

documents.title: Gemini CLI core
documents.summary: This document describes the core package of Gemini CLI, detailing its responsibilities such as interacting with the Gemini API, managing tools, handling prompt engineering, and managing session state. It also covers security considerations, chat history compression, and file/memory discovery services.

documents.title: Policy engine
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Gemini CLI's policy engine to control tool execution through customizable rules, including defining conditions, decisions, and priority tiers.

documents.title: Gemini CLI file system tools
documents.summary: This document details the file system interaction tools available in the Gemini CLI, including functions for listing directories, reading and writing files, finding files with glob patterns, searching file content, and replacing text within files.

documents.title: Web search tool (`google_web_search`)
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the `google_web_search` tool to perform web searches via the Gemini API, detailing its arguments and providing usage examples.

documents.title: Todo tool (`write_todos`)
documents.summary: This document explains the `write_todos` tool in the Gemini CLI, which helps agents break down complex requests into manageable subtasks and track their progress.

documents.title: Memory tool (`save_memory`)
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the `save_memory` tool in the Gemini CLI to store and recall information across sessions by writing facts to a `GEMINI.md` file.

documents.title: Gemini CLI core: Tools API
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and components of the Gemini CLI's tool system, including how tools are defined, registered, discovered, executed, and how their results are processed and displayed.

documents.title: Extension releasing
documents.summary: This document explains two methods for releasing extensions: via a Git repository or GitHub Releases, detailing how to manage release channels and package platform-specific archives.

documents.title: MCP servers with the Gemini CLI
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure and use Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers with the Gemini CLI, detailing the integration architecture, resource handling, and setup process.

documents.title: Getting started with Gemini CLI extensions
documents.summary: This guide explains how to create your first Gemini CLI extension, covering setup, adding custom tools and commands, and providing model context.

documents.title: Gemini CLI extensions
documents.summary: This document explains how to manage Gemini CLI extensions, including installation, uninstallation, enabling/disabling, updating, and creating new extensions. It also details the structure and configuration options for the `gemini-extension.json` file.

documents.title: Package overview
documents.summary: This document explains the structure and purpose of the monorepo containing the Gemini CLI packages, detailing the roles of `@google/gemini-cli` and `@google/gemini-cli-core`, and the benefits of using NPM Workspaces for managing them.

documents.title: IDE integration
documents.summary: This document explains how to integrate the Gemini CLI with your IDE for enhanced features like workspace context awareness and native diffing, covering installation, enabling/disabling, status checking, and troubleshooting common errors.

documents.title: Gemini CLI hooks
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Gemini CLI hooks, which are scripts that run at specific points in the agentic loop to customize behavior. It covers enabling hooks, security risks, available hook events, command hook communication, and input/output contracts for various events.

documents.title: Automation and triage processes
documents.summary: This document explains the automated workflows used to triage issues and pull requests in a repository, detailing how bots label, test, and manage contributions for efficient integration.

documents.title: Writing hooks for Gemini CLI
documents.summary: This guide explains how to create and configure custom hooks for the Gemini CLI to automate tasks, log events, and enhance workflows.

documents.title: Hooks on Gemini CLI: Best practices
documents.summary: This document provides best practices for developing and deploying hooks in Gemini CLI, covering security, performance, debugging, and privacy. It includes guidance on optimizing hook execution speed, caching results, using appropriate events and matchers, handling errors, testing, and documentation.

documents.title: Hooks Reference
documents.summary: This document details the technical specifications for Gemini CLI hooks, explaining how they communicate with the CLI using JSON schemas, standard streams, and exit codes. It covers input and output schemas for various event types and defines the stable model API for LLM interactions.

documents.title: Gemini CLI releases
documents.summary: This document explains the development and production release environments, including how code is promoted between nightly, preview, and stable channels. It also details the automated release process, the source of truth for versioning, and procedures for manual releases and tag changes.

documents.title: Frequently asked questions (FAQ)
documents.summary: This document addresses frequently asked questions and common issues related to the Gemini CLI, covering topics such as API errors, installation, platform-specific problems, configuration, and subscription benefits.

documents.summary: This document outlines the release channels for the Gemini CLI, including nightly, preview, and stable versions, and details recent updates and fixes for the preview release.

documents.title: Integration tests
documents.summary: This document explains how to build, run, and debug integration tests for the Gemini CLI, including options for running specific tests, regenerating model responses, and handling test output.

documents.title: Troubleshooting guide
documents.summary: This document provides solutions to common issues encountered with the Gemini CLI, covering authentication errors, general command errors, and debugging techniques. It also explains how to report new issues or find existing ones on GitHub.

documents.summary: This document provides release notes for a new version of the Gemini CLI, detailing new features such as comprehensive quota visibility, improved CLI statistics, and multi-file drag & drop support, alongside various bug fixes and improvements.

documents.summary: This document specifies the contract for building IDE companion plugins for Gemini CLI, enabling features like IDE mode, context awareness, and interactive code diffing.

documents.summary: This document details the technical specification for Gemini CLI hooks, outlining their communication protocol via standard streams and exit codes, the JSON schemas for input and output, and the stable model API for interacting with language models.

documents.title: Gemini CLI: Quotas and pricing
documents.description: Gemini CLI offers a generous free tier that covers many individual developers' use cases. For enterprise or professional usage, or if you need higher limits, several options are available depending on your authentication account type.
documents.summary: This document explains the different quota and pricing tiers available for the Gemini CLI, including free usage, paid subscriptions, and pay-as-you-go options, based on authentication methods.

documents.title: Gemini CLI extensions
documents.summary: This document explains how to manage Gemini CLI extensions, covering installation, uninstallation, enabling/disabling, updating, creating boilerplate extensions, linking local extensions, and the structure of the `gemini-extension.json` configuration file.
